required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intravenous Tramadol Versus Intravenous Paracetamol in Patients With Dysmenorrhea
clinical_study.official_title: Comparing Efficiencies of Intravenous Paracetamol and Intravenous Tramadol in Patients With Primary Dysmenorrhea Presented in Emergency Department

brief_summary.textblock: Patients presented with primary dysmenorrhea composed the study population. One gram paracetamol and 100 mg tramadol in 100 ml saline with a slow infusion were compared in ceasing dysmenorrhea in the emergency department

detailed_description.textblock: Patients over 18 years old who presented with dysmenorrhea composed the study population. Patients received painkiller within the last six hours, physical findings consistent with peritoneal irritation, allergy to the study drugs, renal or liver failure, drug addiction, pregnancy or woman with lactation and denied to give inform consent were the exclusion criteria. The pain of the study patients is measured with the visual analogue scale at baseline, 15th and 30th minutes and 1 hour after study drug administration. At the end of the 60 minutes, rescue drug need is also recorded.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: acute pain of dysmenorrhea measured by visual analogue scale
primary_outcome.description: Change in visual analogue scale at 15th minutes from baseline

primary_outcome.measure: pain of dysmenorrhea measured by visual analogue scale
primary_outcome.description: Change in visual analogue scale at 30th minutes from baseline

primary_outcome.measure: pain of dysmenorrhea measured by visual analogue scale
primary_outcome.description: Change in visual analogue scale at 60th minutes from baseline

secondary_outcome.description: the need for additional analgesic drug

arm_group.description: Intravenous 100 mg tramadol in 100 ml saline with slow infusion.
Intravenous 1 gm paracetamol in 100 ml saline with slow infusion.

intervention.description: 100 mg tramadol in 100 ml saline with slow infusion
Intravenous 1 gm paracetamol in 100 ml saline with slow infusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with dysmenorrhea
- Patients over 18 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- denied to give inform consent
- Renal or liver failure
- Allergy to the study drugs
- Receiving pain killer within the last 6 hours.
- Physical examination findings consistent with peritoneal irritation
- Pregnancy or patients with lactation
- Drug addiction
